sentence:
11:10 AM CHEST (PORTABLE AP) Clip # Reason: Is their evidence of infectious cause to fevers in the lung Admitting Diagnosis: BACTEREMIA
MEDICAL CONDITION: 39 year old man with ESRD, MSSA bacteremia, and iliopsoas hematomas s/p surgical debridement who is on broad spectrum Abx and had been afebrile for 48hrs, now with fever overnight to 101.2.
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION: Is their evidence of infectious cause to fevers in the lung paranchyma?
FINAL REPORT HISTORY:
Fever, to assess for underlying pneumonia.
FINDINGS:
In comparison with the study of , there is little change.
Central catheter remains in place and a dense granulomatous nodal calcification is again seen on the left.
Specifically, there is no evidence of acute pneumonia to account for the fever of the patient.
6:55 PM CHEST PORT.

LINE PLACEMENT Clip # Reason: 45 cm Picc placed in left basilic vein, need Picc tip placem Admitting Diagnosis: BACTEREMIA
MEDICAL CONDITION: 39 year old man with new picc REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION: 45 cm Picc placed in left basilic vein, need Picc tip placement
WET READ: EAGg SUN 8:17 PM
Distal end of left PICC in mid SVC.
No PTX.
d/ at 8:15 pm.
FINAL REPORT AP CHEST, 7:16 P.M., HISTORY: New PIC line, check placement.
IMPRESSION: AP chest compared to through 15:
Left PIC line ends in the mid SVC.
Heavy prevascular mediastinal nodal calcifications probably granulomatous or collection of treated lymphoma.
Heart size is normal.

There is no pleural abnormality, and the lungs are grossly clear.
PATIENT/TEST INFORMATION:
Indication: Congestive heart failure Height: (in) 71

Weight (lb): 202 BSA (m2): 2.12 m2 BP (mm Hg): 118/84 HR (bpm): 125 Status: Inpatient Date/Time: at 16:12 Test: TTE (Complete) Doppler: Full Doppler and color Doppler Contrast: None Technical Quality: Suboptimal INTERPRETATION:
Findings: LEFT VENTRICLE: Cannot assess LVEF.
LV WALL MOTION: Regional LV wall motion abnormalities include: basal inferior - akinetic; mid inferior - akinetic; RIGHT VENTRICLE: Normal RV wall thickness.
Normal RV chamber size.
RV function depressed.
AORTA:
Normal aortic diameter at the sinus level.
No 2D or Doppler evidence of distal arch coarctation.
MITRAL VALVE:
Normal mitral valve leaflets.
No MVP.
Normal mitral valve supporting structures.
No MS.
Mild (1+) MR. GENERAL COMMENTS: Suboptimal image quality - poor echo windows.
Conclusions:
Overall left ventricular systolic function cannot be reliably assessed but appears depressed, with inferior akinesis.
Right ventricular chamber size is normal, with depressed free wall contractility.
The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal.
There is no mitral valve prolapse.
Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen.
10:48 AM CT PELVIS W/CONTRAST Clip # Reason: Is there abscess or infectious fluid collection in RLQ?

Admitting Diagnosis: BACTEREMIA Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
MEDICAL CONDITION: 39 year old man with with ESRD on HD who was admitted to hospital with MSSA line sepsis.
More recently underwent a surgical intervention for R thigh drainage of hematoma with access through RLQ of abdomen.
Now febrile with RLQ U/S showing fluid collections suspicious for abscess.
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION: Is there abscess or infectious fluid collection in RLQ?

CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: ESRD on HD
PROVISIONAL FINDINGS IMPRESSION (PFI): 3:08 PM PFI: 1.
Two fluid collections in the right anterior abdominal wall, one may be residual hematoma, the other may be fluid, infection is not excluded.
2. Multiple locules of air within the right iliacus muscle, some of which may be post-operative, the remaining may be related to surgical packing with Surgicel.
A small amount of air may be intraperitoneal.
3. Heterogeneous attenuation of the left iliacus muscle may reflect residual hematoma at the site but no locules of air within the left iliacus.
4. Small amount of free fluid within the pelvis.
5. Bilateral renal cysts, the left may be proteinaceous.
FINAL REPORT HISTORY:
End-stage renal disease on hemodialysis, admitted to the hospital with emesis and line sepsis, and recently underwent surgical intervention of the right thigh hematoma drainage.
CT PELVIS:
Helical imaging was performed through the pelvis after IV contrast administration.
No oral contrast present.
Sagittal and coronal reformats were prepared.
COMPARISON: Soft tissue ultrasound , CT pelvis , and MR .
CT PELVIS:
There is a hypodense cyst within the right kidney (2:2).
There is an additional probable simple cyst within the left kidney (2:5).
No hydronephrosis is present.
The inferior margin of the liver appears normal.
Pelvic loops of bowel are normal in their appearance.
Bladder is unremarkable.
There is intermediate density fluid in the dependent portion of the pelvis (2:46), new.
There is no significant adenopathy.
There is marked heterogeneous attenuation in the left iliacus muscle, which (Over) 10:48 AM CT PELVIS W/CONTRAST Clip # Reason:
Is there abscess or infectious fluid collection in RLQ?

Admitting Diagnosis: BACTEREMIA Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
FINAL REPORT (Cont) appears enlarged.
There is no air within the left iliacus muscle (2:33).
There are multiple locules of air within the right iliacus muscle (2:28) compatible with surgical packing with Surgicel.
The right iliacus is heterogeneous in its attenuation, which may reflect residual blood products.
More anteriorly within the iliacus muscle is an additional locule of air.
It is unclear if this area extends intraperitoneal (2:26).
In the right anterior abdominal wall is a poorly defined fluid collection measuring 4.4 x 2.2 cm and containing several locules of air (2:40).
Underlying right anterior abdominal wall skin staples is a dense 4.6 x 2.2 cm collection which may represent residual hematoma.
There are multiple extensive locules of air in the anterior and right abdominal wall, similar to the prior examination.
Skin staples overlie the left anterior abdominal wall.
BONE AND SOFT TISSUE WINDOWS: There are no suspicious-appearing sclerotic or lytic lesions.
There is no evidence for bone destruction as cortical margins along the margin of the right and left iliacus remain well defined without evidence for osteomyelitis.
There is anasarca.
IMPRESSION:
Two fluid collections in the right anterior abdominal wall, one may be residual hematoma, the other may be fluid, infection is not excluded.
2. Multiple locules of air within the right iliacus muscle, some of which may be post-operative, the remaining may be related to surgical packing with Surgicel.
A small amount of air may be intraperitoneal.
Persistent large amount of air in the anterior abdominal wall, fascititis is not excluded.
4. Heterogeneous attenuation of the left iliacus muscle may reflect residual hematoma at the site but no locules of air within the left iliacus.
5. Small amount of free fluid within the pelvis.
Findings were discussed with Dr. of the orthopedic service at 2 p.m. on .
3:31 PM CHEST PORT.
LINE PLACEMENT; -77

BY DIFFERENT PHYSICIAN # Reason: 1520
MEDICAL CONDITION: 39 year old man with new RIJ HD line REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION: line placement
FINAL REPORT TYPE OF EXAMINATION:
Chest, AP portable single view.
INDICATION: 39-year-old male patient with new right internal jugular hemodialysis line.
Check placement.
FINDINGS:
AP single view of the chest has been obtained with patient in sitting semi-upright position.

A wide caliber double-lumen hemodialysis catheter has been inserted via the right internal jugular approach and its tip is overlying the right-sided upper mediastinum terminating at level 1 cm below the carina.
This is compatible with a location in the mid portion of the SVC.
No pneumothorax is seen.
Heart size is normal.
No evidence of pulmonary vascular congestion or acute infiltrates.

11:50 AM MR HIP W/O CONRAST BILAT Clip # Reason: eval for infection, acute process; please obtain imaging of Admitting Diagnosis: BACTEREMIA
MEDICAL CONDITION: 39 year old man with right hip pain, MSSA bacteremia REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION: eval for infection, acute process; please obtain imaging of pelvis down to lower trochanter to assess for vascular abnormalities/AVN CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: ESRD Yes to Choyke questions.
WET READ: KRmb SUN 5:28 PM Limited by lack of Gadolinium due to renal failure.
Bilateral iliacus abscesses, multiloculated, right larger than left.
Some hemorrhagic components.
Associated adjacent myositis in the right upper thigh.
No hip joint to suggest septic arthritis.
No extension into the spinal canal or psoas muscles.

K. Rafatzand, Body MRI fellow
FINAL REPORT MRI OF THE HIPS, CLINICAL HISTORY:
Right hip pain, MSSA bacteremia.
COMPARISON: Ultrasound .
TECHNIQUE:
Multiplanar T1- and T2-weighted images of the right hip and pelvis was acquired on a 1.5 Tesla magnet without contrast per department protocol.
FINDINGS:
Evaluation is slightly limited due to lack of intravenous contrast, which could not be administered due to chronic renal insufficiency.
Within these limits, there is evidence of bilateral multiloculated fluid collections in the iliopsoas musculature, right greater than left.

On the right, heterogeneous T2 hyperintense, and mainly T1 hypointense material within the right iliacus muscle markedly expands this area, with heterogeneous collection measuring approximately 12 x 5.5 x 4.4 cm (7, 15 and 9, 15).
This extends along the iliopsoas tendon on the right.
There are internal fluid-fluid levels with areas of T1 hyperintensity which may represent blood products or proteinaceous debris.
On the left, similar but smaller heterogeneously T2 hyperintense fluid collection measures 3.9 x 3.5 x 2.1 cm (7, 15 and 9, 19).
There is edema in the surrounding musculature on both sides, consistent with myositis, which extends into the right upper thigh, more evident on the right than on the left.
Adjacent to the distal iliopsoas tendon on the right, there is a small area of fluid signal just behind the rectus femoris, measuring 13 x 14 mm (9, 44).
There is no evidence of any bowel communication.
There is no definite communication with the paraspinal musculature.
Proximal psoas musculature bilaterally appears within normal limits (9, 19).

Visualized intrapelvic contents are otherwise unremarkable, except to note (Over) 11:50 AM MR HIP W/O CONRAST BILAT Clip # Reason: eval for infection, acute process; please obtain imaging of Admitting Diagnosis: BACTEREMIA
FINAL REPORT (Cont) trace free pelvic fluid.
There is no hip effusion on either side.
Visualized marrow signal is moderately heterogeneous, but probably represents red marrow reconversion versus sequelae of renal failure.
Surrounding soft tissues are otherwise unremarkable.
IMPRESSION: 1. Bilateral heterogeneous fluid collections in the iliacus muscles, most consistent with abscesses, right greater than left.
Fluid-fluid levels with areas of T1 hyperintensity suggest the presence of internal hemorrhage and/or proteinaceous debris.
Collection on the right extends into the iliopsoas bursa, with associated myositis, and small area of focal fluid near the rectus femoris origin.
No evidence of hip effusions.
Sinus tachycardia.
Left bundle-branch block.
Since the previous tracing of there is probably no significant change.
Sinus tachycardia.
Probable incomplete left bundle-branch block.
Since the previous tracing of no significant change.
